SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth?

How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? [Signature]

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation?

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.?

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take pot luck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "cook after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? [Signature]

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many houses were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Saturday

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Occasionally

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand?

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take off" used or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay at home to "watch after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activities? Yes

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times; every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

for social entertainments and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country,
did you continue to use the local school house for literary gatherings, etc.,
or come to the hall in town for other festivities, or were you close enough to
make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.)

Was there card playing for a prize?

the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community or were there
some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for
community gatherings? Explain.

United until lunch time then all went home

One year 1907 we all drove 30 miles out to a place near the lake where we had a big lunch and then walked over the city and up the country side. We saw what they could build from found flint arrow heads and our friend and hunting knife.

What year? 1905

How long did it continue? It is still going on.
